22:42 The Universe is not magically accelerating.
In fact the nonsense stems from the fact that we can see further and further away and thus
see something larger than we expected or calculated.
The Universe is slowing down, but not fast enough for the cohesion to catch up.
Also, when taking into account that the measurements we take are data from the age
measured in distance divided by the speed of light, or rather years over lightyears,
the further out we use that data, the older it is.
When you then do comparatives with different datasets, which all imply a specific point in time,
comparison apples to oranges starts.
They'd first have to calculate the set back into an all same timeperiod, and then do comparison.
Then it'll show a slight decline in speed, but not enough to counter the outward motion.
So, basically you look at something that's like 13.5 billion lightyears away,
you take into account deceleration for a period of 13.5 billion years,
you extend the vector of it's position from the center of the Big Bang accordingly,
to calculate it's position in current time, and now you do the same for another observed
point in space, also recalculated for the current time, and now you have one correct dataset,
one frame, for a comparison with another frame, which then involves doing the same objects
again over time, and repeating that until you have enough frames for an accurate comparison,
where observational differences and measuring equipments variation become less significant.
Then you can tell if things are speeding up or slowing down.
I'm certain it's not speeding up.

20:18 Photons do not change their speed, so, with time anything that emits photons our way will become visible.
It may take a decillion years to reach our position as it would be in a decillion years from now,
but it will reach that position, in spite of any speed or distance of the emitting source.

Note: The emission source may be so far away that we may only receive a single photon
of the emission source on a telescope of 10 km wide, and yet that photon would still be coming
from something so far away that it would have taken a decillion years from now to reach us.
(1 decillion LY)

20:45 Common misunderstanding, light emitted, once emitted will stay travelling at c.
Even if an object would move away at 10x c, once the photon leaves it and has a course that will bring it to us
in x years, it would still travel at c.
The object itself and it's speed have no bearing on the light reaching us, once emitted from the source.
And like said, a speed differential may exceed c, for up to 2c, and even then the object itself does not
have to exceed c.
Let's say we travel at 0.1 c from the Big Bang, and we see an object travel at 0.95 c away from
the center of the Big Bang in the opposite direction, the speed differential would 1.05 c,
but the object itself would still only be at 0.95 c and thus not exceed the speed of light.
But even with this speed differential any light emitted from that source would still reach us,
since we only travel at 0.1 c and once emitted the photon would still travel at c towards us.

19:33 Well, the further we can actually see, the faster that would be moving away from us.
Any distance from the center of the Big Bang can only mean that the minimum speed of the object,
beit galaxy or star, has moved within the timeframe of teh start of the Big Bang to how far it is
from the center, which in turn indicates speed.
Although I do believe that the speed of light for any physical object may be limited by the speed of light,
it is however possible to exceed a speed differential by a factor of 2.
Two photons, one left and one right move away from each other, speed differential 2c.
But, for physical matter to stay cohesive the absolute speed of light may
be a barrier which when broken by whichever means would cease cohesion.

I myself am a believer that speed is not relative but absolute, although from a human perspective
we can only measure it relative to something else, but that's about to change using the same methodology
as advanced LIGO for such measurements in which case we can tell speed in comparison to a photon,
and with said vector then being reduced by the vector of the photon, we can determine absolute speed.

16:46 Light vs. the start of the Universe, means speed times time, expressed both in years
and lightspeed, meaning lightyears. We can actually tell that the size of the Universe
is larger than we can actually see, simply by knowing it comes from all sides, but us not
being the center means that some light is still travelling to us.

Also on top of that there's what we see of the Universe, which is then equally old information.
If the distance is 1 million light years, it depicts the situation of the Universe as it was
a million years ago, which in turn means that depending on which side you extrapolate
we can also figure out where something would be today, which then also adds
to the maximum distance we know to exist in the Universe.

One thing is for certain, we have not yet reached the limit of the Universe and with that
a new information may actually be gathered and that is that not all of the matter within
is aged the same way, and that we may yet be in a newer or older part of this formation.
This in turn would then also express that there's yet much more Universe 'filler' than we know.

In fact at 17:07, when you take into account that the furthest we have seen in the Universe
is 13.5 billion years ago, that that happened 13.5 billion years ago at that distance,
means that 13.5 billion LY, 13.5 billion years ago, there was a galaxy HD1 or gn-Z11
at that distance. So 13.5 billion LY away, 13.5 billion years ago, means 13.5 billion LY+
travel over 13.77 trillion years at the speed of that galaxy in comparison to ours..

Cutes, don't be fooled.
The volume of the universe can't and won't expand because it's limitless. There's no end.
The matter in the universe may spread further and further apart, but that does not increase the space,
just the part that has substance in it.

For light, the Universe's filling expands at the speed of light, since outward light never returns,
and that globe is at least the size of the age of the Universe in LY, so a 27.5B LY globe.
For the matter however, it's much less, but still expands.

(If the Universe's volume was not limitless light would be returning to us for all intent and purpose, bouncing back.)
Also, the age of the Universe may be much larger than we know, which then means a much larger globe of light.

Also, yet again, it's not the Universe that expands, just the matter within it we see moving away.
Volume stable, distance between matter increases within this infinite space.

Imagine that you had a spaceship that can reach speeds in excess of 1000km/s. Lets say that you want to travel to Proxima Centauri which is 4-LY (40,208,000,000,000) km away. It would take 1275 years to reach the nearest star but that is not the only problem.The observational position of a star is an illusion. Proxima Centauri is 4LY away which means you are observing that star's passed location. Proxima Centauri is moving therefore its current location is not where you see it. The first thing you must do is gather data on the star's current location in real time. To travel to our nearest neighbor you will need to predict the star's future position then navigate to that point when you will rendez-vous with Proxima in 1275 years.

All those galaxies are not moving away from us. We are in fact moving away from each other. In other words, if you pick a point halfway between any two equally distant objects they would be moving away from that point at the very same rate.

Also, the observable universe is unique to your position. For the voyager probes and us the observable universe is shifted about 21.5 light hours...not too large an amount compared to 13.7 billion light years, but still, a very slightly different universe.

For a being living at the very edge of our observable universe, the universe we have in common is the intersection of the two observer centric spheres. And when they look at the same galaxy close to them, in our direction, they see it in a MUCH more recent configuration...and that is a mind game proof that their time and our time are billions of years different.

But the thing is, you wouldn't know if the space between atoms is expanding, or rather, you wouldn't know if the expansion of space is causing the space between atoms to expand, since any attempt to measure these spaces would be subjected to the same expansion of space. What I mean is, if you were using a 30cm/ 1 foot ruler to measure the space between atoms (just as an example. I mean, let's pretend that they're giant, SUPER-atoms). Now if the ruler was constant, then you'd be able to measure any expansion of the space between atoms. However, if your ruler was also expanding at the same rate as the space between atoms, then it would appear that the space between atoms has remained constant, even though it's been expanding at a rate that is unmeasurable, due to the very expansion that's causing... the... err... expansion!!!

By the way I believe that many of the plates that Hubble used were actually taken on the Mt Wilson telescopes by other people, the night observers. In most cases I'm sure Hubble requested the images be taken. I would need to talk to some people to get the names. Some of these people were amazingly talented at guiding the plates on the sky for a clear exposure and taking many images to get very good images in moments of good seeing.

Operating telescopes back then was not easy to say the least. Both the telescope operator and the observer would spend the whole night in the dome with the telescope regardless of the weather. Mainly the cold and the wind in the winter, at least they did not need to worry about rain. :) Guiding the plates required constant attention to get a good image. You needed to sit at the telescope and watch a guide star through an eye piece and constantly adjust the position of the telescope to keep the star lined up on the same point on the plate, sometimes for hours. I believe that there were even plates that were exposed for multiple days.

A few years ago, where I work, they pulled out the original VAR! plate for all us to look at.  Of course it looked like the reproductions but it was still wonderful to see the plate that literally changed our understanding of the scale of the universe by many orders of magnitude.  Of course the VAR! plate and the distance to the Andromeda galaxy is only the first part of the story of our understanding of the expansion of the universe.

Bottom line, each point in space is getting further apart from each other due to the fact the the space they are in is expanding. Like dots on the surface of a balloon that is getting inflated. But volumetrically not just on the surface. And since the further apart 2 points are the faster they are pulling apart, at one point they end up moving apart faster than the speed of light (relative to each other - not because they are moving faster than light but because the distance between them (rate of expansion) increases in a given time more than the space light can travel through in the same time). When that happens information cannot reach across, disappear from each other and basically they become completely unreachable to each other on any level. Eventually every star outside the Milky Way (and Andromeda, which is a collision course with it) will disappear and become completely physically unreachable.

If you want to understand expansion of the universe, all you need to do is look at how molecules react in the void of air, or water. In other words space is a kind of fluid and depending on radiation it expands or contracts, the same way has molecules expand or contract based on temperature. Light photons can travel throw most mediums but not all which can give the illusion of loss. Even with the red shift, both gravity and different mediums in space can create illusions of expansion. Other possibilities are that galaxies collide with other galaxies which can cause the illusion of super fast expansion. The last factor is time in relation to speed, which just adds a new variable.  Add all these together and yes the universe is expanding, but that expansion is unpredictable. That unpredictability is what constantly keeps us guessing, but that is also what makes science fun and leads to new discoveries.

An easy to understand analogy of the expanding universe, and how light speed is relative, is if you think of light moving at 100kmh, and two cars driving away from each other at 50.5kmh, so relative speed of 101kmh, can still see each other, even though the relative speed is faster than light speed. The cars are fixed points inn the fabric of an expanding universe.
Now for a horrifying point. If the outer edge of the actual universe expands to the point where physics can no longer hold it together, the shock wave of the universe falling apart will travel back at the speed of light, which creates a paradox. The shock wave would hit us at the speed of light so we would never know it happened due to us not being able to see it coming and immediately ceasing to exist when it hit, BUT, as the boundary of the universe is moving away faster than the speed of light relative to us, it would never actually get to us. It is equivalent to someone shooting a bullet at 50kmh out the back of a car driving at 100kmh. The bullet still moves at 50kmh in the SAME direction as the car. -50 + 100 = 50. The more questions that are answered about the universe, the more complex and mind blowing it becomes.

Dr Mack should be a little cautious in using the word 'never' about what we might know in the future as our knowledge of the fundamental laws of nature is incomplete. Not only do we think one or both of General Relativity and Quantum Mechanics is wrong, but many theoretical physicists believe that at a more fundamental level neither space nor time exist! If so, emphatic statements about what me might never know about some point in spacetime may be a little premature. Of course, 'we' - as in ourselves as individuals or our species - may never know as we may well all be dead before anyone figures it out!

In the late 1800s early 1900s people asked themselves about the nature of light. Maxwell's equations had predicted an "electro-magnetic" wave and physicists were looking for the "medium" through which this wave propagated. They eventually came with this idea of aether, a medium which was everywhere and very rigid and very soft at the same time. Michelson and Morley's experiment put it to rest and it was assumed this aether was not a background thing through which (and relative to which) objects moved.
In 1905 special theory of relativity showed aether was not needed and all you had to bear in mind to describe movement (at least constant-velocity movement) was reference frames.
Now, cosmology says movement is relative to space and it has this déjà vu feeling over it. When I move, do I move relative to a fixed background? Relative to other objects in space? Relative to inertial reference frameworks? The issue I have with the idea that it is space itself that expands as per Hubble's law and not limited by the speed of light is that in order to explain why that is possible, the same kind of arguments that were given to discuss the existence of the aether are used.

I know absolutely nothing about cosmology, but a thought occurred to me about another way to think about the 'expansion' of the universe:

What if instead of everything expanding, and things further away expanding more - everything is static from a global perspective but all matter is shrinking in size, making it appear locally as though things are getting further away because our yardstick to measure with is also shrinking. So imagine a 2D grid with a couple of circles on it to represent pockets of matter. Each grid is spaced apart by some unit length. At the start we could imagine 3 circles of diameter 1: one is at the center of our grid (0,0), the second is one unit to the right (1,0), and the third is 10 units to the right (10,0). If we are the circle at (0,0) then when we observe the other two circles, they appear to be 1 unit and 10 units away, respectively. Then imagine some later time where all matter shrinks in size the same amount, but stays exactly at the same original grid locations. From this global perspective we can see the circles all have diameter 0.5 and are all at the same locations on the original grid. From our perspective on the now shrunken circle at (0,0) though, we have unknowingly shrunk and thus so has our local 'yardstick' with which to measure distance. So we look at the sphere originally at location (1,0) and see that it is now actually at (2,0) because we and our measurement devices unknowingly shrunk to half the size, so we would say it has some velocity of 1 unit per elapsed time. Similarly the third sphere which was originally at (10,0) is now at (20,0) and we would conclude it has velocity of 10 units per elapsed time. Thus things that appear further away appear to be moving further away faster and faster

does that make any sense to anyone? I haven't seen it phrased this way, but it sometimes makes it easier for me to intuitively understand. Put a bunch of circles on a 2D surface, keep them all at the same global location, shrink them all, then zoom in onto any one of them so as to keep it 'locally' the same size, and you would see that all of the other circles look to be moving faster, the further away they are

Similarly, if you could theoretically observe the entire universe all at once from some global perspective, you would simply see it is static in size and that everything inside is just shrinking in place. For some reason this makes more sense and brings me a little more peace than the idea of infinity expanding further into infinity.

The idea that there is some universal 'now' with respect to any frame of reference just seems highly suspect to me.
